International regulation is required if we want to quell these geopolitical conflicts and address global warming, but it would need countries to reaffirm their political will so it would be heard by the global private stakeholders who govern the world’s energy trade.

Conversely, the wide use of renewable energies would redistribute the sources of production across different regions, thereby reducing the challenge of appropriating limited and unevenly distributed resources on the planet. Consequently, this would defuse many international conflicts. This would finally leave international bodies to deal with other issues, such as education, women’s conditions, happiness, etc.

Metals need energy and energy needs metals.

While between 8 and 10% of the world’s primary energy is used to mine or refine metals, 5% of the world’s steel is currently used to extract oil and gas. Highly energy-intensive processes are needed to mine these precious metals that are found in many of our everyday objects. As the concentration of metals in the earth diminishes, an increasing amount of energy is required to extract them. A little bit like a love story which could end badly, some people are talking about a “peak all”, a threshold when we will simultaneously reach the limits of our resources of oil, gas and the main metals.

While renewable energies (wind farms and solar panels) are also dependent on metals, they require much smaller amounts. Unless we find new technologies that do not depend on rare, energy-intensive resources, only a radical change in our production methods and consumption patterns could collectively lead us into a virtuous circle.

Environmental and societal issues (for example, climate change, biodiversity loss, food security and water management) are leading to the redevelopment of collective coordination methods. It is a matter of managing “common goods” with a long-term approach, rising above the economic interests of different countries and private stakeholders.

International standards and agreements are being drafted within various frameworks: international treaties, multilateral agreements, Conferences of the Parties, etc., during international environmental negotiations and various forums. The involvement of stakeholders on a global level, such as the COP21 for the climate, brings in non-governmental organisations (NGOs) and private individuals, without whom it would not be possible to implement anything effective or sustainable.

Does a world population exist? Are we all “citizens of the world”? At a time when the Internet is revolutionising our relationship with power, institutions and citizenship, do we have to plan for a “global democracy”?

While over half of the world’s population live under the yoke of authoritarian regimes, the democratic model is often considered as the best form of public organisation for society and the most respectful of individual rights. Nevertheless, it is being increasingly challenged, in particular with regard to the lack of example set by the major democracies.

Furthermore, is it wise to hope to secure international agreements with undemocratic regimes for the general interest of the population, when some people think that these regimes have little concern for their own people?

While some people dispute the very idea of a global democracy, many authorities (countries, scientists, civil society representatives, etc.) are making their voices heard within international institutional organisations, calling for general interests to be prioritised over national interests.

“In the 21st century, health is a shared responsibility, involving equitable access to essential care and collective defence against transnational threats” (WHO, 2014).

The recent epidemic of the extremely viral and often fatal Ebola virus in West Africa clearly emphasised the need for international cooperation in healthcare. In addition to the Ebola crisis, there has been the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS), the polio outbreak in the Middle East and Africa, as well as the plague in Madagascar. These are only the latest examples of the difficulty governments face in controlling the spread of infectious diseases when they work alone: the global rules negotiated among governmental authorities are vital for protecting citizens’ health (Source: Finance & Development, December 2014).

Access to drinking water and a sufficiently rich diet are the first building block of access to health. Similarly to the right to food, health is a human right. However, private pharmaceutical industries are turning health into a real market economy. The boundary line between private and public interests is blurred, making the regulation system highly complex and questioning the feasibility of an equitable, fair and effective healthcare system.

There will be between 9 and 10 billion people by 2050. There will be just as many mouths to feed, families to house, children to look after, energy to provide, etc. Some people think that we will have to curb global population growth in light of future environmental, social and economic global challenges. But is that even possible? History shows us that demographic policies have little effect.

While experience tells us that demographic transition, which leads to a stabilised population following a fall in birth and death rates, is directly linked to a population’s economic and social development and more specifically to the educational level of women.

The world’s population is not just growing but is moving around the world as well: climate refugees, flows of epidemics, brain drain, tax avoidance, etc. Do we have to control migratory flows? How can we implement fair global governance which takes into account countries’ specific interests without undermining individual freedoms? Global governance of the population poses more questions than answers and for each issue it leads us to make a decision on the world we want to live in, celebrating all our diversity.

Countries’ interdependence, in particular from an economic and commercial perspective, is a major factor in global stability or instability: if a country’s economy slows down, it can affect the economies of its neighbouring countries. The 2007 financial crisis, which began in the United States and then snowballed around the whole world, highlighted the need for global financial regulation.

Even though there are certain institutions, organisations and summits, such as the IMF (International Monetary Fund), the FSC (Financial Stability Committee), the G20 summit and the Basel Committee, the markets generally remain beyond the control of the State. Founded after the Second World War, these institutions specifically aimed to improve the stability of the global economy and therefore to bring forward its recognition as a global public good.

Are the existing international standards sufficient when faced with the power and automation of the financial markets? Can we still believe in a fully transparent financial system regulated by the State, when some countries seem to take orders from this financial system?

While two thirds of the world’s population could find themselves suffering from “water stress” by 2025, international management of drinking water is becoming essential in certain regions around the world to guarantee its protection and access. Water is essential for life and a human right, a global public good. However, 11% of the world’s population does not currently have access to water. This plague no longer only blights the least developed countries. Recently, the inhabitants of Detroit in the United States had to appeal to the UN after too many people had their water cut off.

Agriculture uses 70% of drinking water for watering. Effective and intelligent allocation of water is therefore essential, as new forms of irrigation come to light. This task is made all the more difficult by the tensions between advocates of global public management and private stakeholders looking to make a profit on their investments. International institutions have been set up, such as the World Water Council, to encourage discussion and provide a global perspective on water issues.

“Blue gold” is a dwindling resource, which creates tensions in areas such as the Golan Heights in the Middle East, the Mekong in Asia and even along the Nile in Africa.

Si les Anglais se réjouissent de bientôt pouvoir produire du bon vin grâce à un climat plus clément, l’insécurité alimentaire pourrait empirer sous l’effet des dérèglements climatiques : cyclones plus violents, canicules plus fréquentes, disparition des deltas fertiles ou avancée des déserts sur les savanes, les effets sur l’agriculture seront dramatiques. Cela pourrait entrainer pertes de récoltes, baisses de rendements, hausse des prix des denrées alimentaires, baisse des revenus des agriculteurs et migrations massives depuis les régions affectées vers les régions voisines.

En 2010, les sécheresses en Russie et en Australie, couplée avec les inondations au Pakistan ont produit un triplement du prix du blé. En 2012, le Midwest américain a connu la pire sécheresse en 50 ans, ce qui a réduit la récolte de maïs attendue de 25% et participé à l’augmentation à des prix du maïs dans le monde, en hausse de près de 40%. L’Afrique, continent le plus concerné par l’insécurité alimentaire, sera durement touché : on estime qu’au-delà d’un réchauffement global de 2 degrés, la production agricole de l’Afrique subsaharienne pourrait décroître de 20% à 30% d’ici à 2080.

Mais le problème est fort complexe : si l’agriculture, surtout tropicale, va fortement souffrir avec le réchauffement climatique, elle en est aussi une des causes principales : on estime qu’actuellement elle émet de 20 à 25 % des gaz à effet de serre. Avec le développement prévu de l’élevage dans le monde, elle devrait émettre le tiers des gaz à effet de serre à échéance 2030 !

The issue of food security is at the heart of the challenges of building sustainable societies. Furthermore, the crossover between food issues and environmental issues and health hazards has largely contributed to the spread of the very challenges of sustainable development.

In terms of the environment, agriculture, which covers a large part of the planet’s surface, is directly affected by global warming and the increasing shortage of natural resources. The same applies for the seas and their fish resources. For land, water, biodiversity and the energy model, there has never been such a pressing urgency to find new management models so that the methods used for food today do not prevent future generations from feeding themselves properly.

We must now find ecologically intensive agricultural techniques, which produce better quality and quantity but use less non-renewable resources. From an economic perspective, when facing the challenge of feeding 9 to 10 billion people in 2050, it is essential that farmers can earn a living from their job and even invest to improve production. Due to the world’s growing population, we will need all the farmers in the world and we must therefore ensure that the most powerful do not suffocate the most vulnerable agricultural models.

From a social point of view, everyone’s right to eat and to eat well must remain a leading objective for the international community. As proven during previous centuries, hunger creates insecurity, forced emigration, epidemics, wars, piracy, terrorism, etc. Humanity pays a heavy price!

Dictatorships and totalitarian regimes develop very different strategies for the food security of their people:
- Some really invest in this issue and try to develop agriculture to meet local needs. For example, it cannot be denied that the Chinese regime has had some great victories in this area and has proven to be much more effective than the democratic systems of India or Vietnam.
- While others like North Korea seem to have little concern for the food security of their people, sometimes even creating chronic malnourishment and famine.

This widespread shortage for the population is both hidden from the media and the international community and, conversely, exposed and highlighted. By finding scapegoats, this orchestrated exposure can legitimise local power and obtain international aid, which is often mostly funnelled off by the group in power. Unfortunately, the democratic system in itself is not an effective guarantee for food security. However, in some cases, the democratic checks and balances in force can help civil society organisations to overhaul failing governments in the face of public opinion, or indeed bring them before their supreme court. Programmes like “Zero Hunger”, which was implemented in Brazil by Lula’s government, have produced dramatic results, to the extent that they have been officially adopted by the United Nations. It is a matter of practically implementing economic and social rights and, in particular, the right to food, complementing other civil rights.

Citizen participation is absolutely essential for creating sustainable progress in these issues, but it actually only seems to be exercised within the democratic framework.

Sufficient food and access to drinking water are the two leading conditions needed for good health.

Even when hunger and malnourishment do not directly kill people, they severely damage their state of health, especially during childhood. Vitamin, protein and micronutrient deficiencies open the door to numerous diseases: anaemia, hypothyroidism, hypothermia, beriberi, pellagra and scurvy, which can lead to diarrhoea, vomiting and bleeding. Long-term malnutrition considerably reduces the intellectual capabilities of those affected, lowering their ability to achieve an increase in wealth throughout their lives, representing a total loss of global GDP of between 2 and 3%. At the other extreme, lifestyles in industrialised societies can lead to an excessively rich and unbalanced diet, mainly consisting of too much sugar, fat, salt and meat. In 2015, a quarter of humanity is overweight and obesity affects 700 million people. It is estimated that overeating kills 2.6 million people each year from cardiovascular diseases, diabetes, hypertension, cirrhosis, cancer, etc. This epidemic dramatically affects the middle classes in developing countries and the working classes in rich countries.

The widespread consumption of processed food packed with artificial ingredients and additives (flavourings, colourings, solvents, sweeteners, stabilisers, preservatives, gelling agents, etc.) is causing the unprecedented growth of food allergies and intolerances. This phenomenon already affects a quarter of the French population and this figure will rise to 50% before 2050. Moreover, long-term exposure to toxic products from the pesticides used in farming and food preservation is causing the emergence of new diseases which are hard to detect and treat.

Last but not least, large amounts of the antibiotics extensively used on industrial livestock farms and fisheries remain in the meat and fish we eat, causing us to build up a resistance to these drugs. This then renders antibiotic treatments ineffective when we catch certain illnesses.

Many people think that countries suffering from starvation will not be able to resolve this problem unless they adopt a strict birth control policy. However, the issue is more complex than that.

The number of malnourished people has remained relatively stable since the beginning of the 20th century, even though the world’s population has grown from 1.8 billion to 7.2 billion in 2015. Even if we cannot clearly reach a satisfactory conclusion to this situation, we can still recognise that our planet has managed to feed an extra 5.4 billion people, in little over a century, and has done so with a much richer and varied diet.

We can see that people are eating much better in China in 2015 under Xi Jinping, with 1.3 billion inhabitants, than under Mao Tsé-tung when there were only 700 million Chinese people, or under the emperors when there were only 400 million. In fact, most major world powers developed precisely at the same time as when their population was growing. Indeed, populations stop growing and plateau naturally when they become rich and not the other way round.

A different problem then occurs. The economic development of families and the middle classes leads to major changes in their eating habits, in particular involving a substantial increase in their consumption of meat and animal proteins. For example, in China in 1980, each person on average ate 14 kilos of meat, while this figure currently stands at 60 kilos. Today, Americans eat 115 kg of meat on average per year and Europeans eat 80 kg. China therefore now consumes about twice as much meat as the United States.

Global food security is not threatened by population growth, but rather by the consumption patterns of the middle classes and the richest population groups.

At the end of the 20th century, agriculture had gradually slipped from the mind of global finance; the sector suffered from a serious lack of investment in most countries around the world. But in the 21st century, it has seen a spectacular turnaround, especially following the 2007 food crisis. Many financial organisations realised that they could speculate on the highly volatile price of agricultural raw materials and could therefore hopefully earn large sums of money. This causes very pronounced fluctuations in the price of commodities (cereals, soya, sugar, oils, etc.). The price of basic foodstuffs can therefore double or triple in just a few weeks, increasing food insecurity and causing food riots. On the other hand, these prices can collapse, driving farmers into overwhelming financial problems. Governments are unable to regulate this phenomenon in the face of economic and financial superpowers.

Due to the shortage of agricultural production, arable land has also become the subject of international speculation. We are therefore seeing a frantic race among certain financial institutions to purchase or lease farmland on all continents. Land grabbing has involved between 100 and 200 million hectares since 2005, favouring the procurement of investor countries to the detriment of the local populations that have been living on these lands for generations.

There is now a huge disproportion in the resources of the different agricultural players. The biggest cooperatives are dwarfed by the champions of agribusiness (seeds and pesticides: Monsanto, Dupont, Syngenta, Bayer, Dow, Limagrain, etc.), agri-food (Nestlé, Unilever, Danone, etc.), international trade (Cargill, Dreyfus, Archer Daniels Midland, Bunge, etc.) or major supermarkets (Wal Mart, Carrefour, etc.). Financial logic is therefore being enforced everywhere. In turn, two new sectors are creating substantial tension between public goods and private interests:
- genetics and the ownership of seeds and living organisms in general;
- information on field fertility, micro-local weather, as well as cultivation and husbandry practices (agricultural big data).

Plants need a huge amount of water to grow because their sap is circulated via a capillary action and transpiration. For example, about a tonne of water is needed to produce a kilo of cereal, which is an enormous amount!

While the Earth may be known as the “blue planet” due to its incredible amount of water, 97% of this water is salt water and therefore unfit for agriculture or livestock. Out of its 3% of fresh water, only a third is accessible (the other two thirds are frozen in permanent ice, or located too deep in the soil or too far away from farmland). Unfortunately, this precious 1% of the world’s usable water is very unevenly distributed: 10 countries have 60% of the world’s water, while 80 countries are suffering from drought. Agriculture is the leading user of fresh water: it takes more than two thirds of the water drawn from rivers, lakes and aquifers, while 1 field in 7 on the planet is currently irrigated.

In many countries, development is being held back because agriculture, industry and towns are arguing over water. These disputes are going to multiply throughout the 21st century across all levels: between farmers in the same village, between farmers and city workers, between upstream and downstream areas of rivers, between countries bordering the same river, etc.

In desert regions like South Sahel in Africa, the subsoil is waterlogged. It has the greatest potential for new arable land on the planet, which could develop farming and provide food security for future generations.

While the English may be looking forward to being able to produce a good wine in the near future thanks to a milder climate, food security could worsen under the effects of climate change: stronger storms, more frequent heatwaves, the disappearance of fertile deltas and the encroaching of deserts on the savannahs could all have dramatic effects on agriculture. This could lead to loss of crops, lower yields, higher food prices, lower incomes for farmers and mass migrations from affected areas to neighbouring regions.

In 2010, droughts in Russia and Australia, coupled with floods in Pakistan, trebled the price of wheat. In 2012, the American Midwest experienced its worst drought in 50 years, which reduced the expected corn harvest by 25% and contributed to a rise in the price of corn around the world, up to almost 40%. As the continent most concerned by food insecurity, Africa will be hard hit: it is estimated that if the world’s temperature increased by more than 2 degrees, agricultural production in Sub-Saharan Africa could decrease by 20 to 30% by 2080.

But the problem is more complex than that: if agriculture, especially tropical farming, is going to suffer badly from global warming, it is also one of its leading causes: it is estimated that agriculture currently releases between 20 and 25% of greenhouse gases. With the planned development of livestock farming around the world, it is predicted to release a third of greenhouse gases by 2030!

Only a century ago, agriculture essentially used solar energy and human or animal power. Since then, we have replaced draught power with tractors and natural organic fertilisers with chemical fertilisers. Between 1960 and 2010, cereal production around the world has undoubtedly tripled over the same area, but at the cost of a 9 fold increase in our consumption of nitrogen fertilisers! To put food on the plate of a European every day, intensive farming must use 4,000 litres of water and 4 litres of oil! Not to mention the increased transportation: in Great Britain, 1.6 billion litres of oil are required just to import the animal feed, while in the USA, food has travelled on average 2,400 km before it arrives on your plate.

Moreover, farmers are now being asked to produce both food and energy in the same fields: will we have to choose between eating and driving? In 2015, Europe will have already devoted over 5 million hectares to biofuels (essentially rapeseed biodiesel), while in the USA, 40% of corn is used to make ethanol. Oil palm plantations for fuel are expected to reach between 35 and 54 million hectares by 2030. This could cause an average rise of 35% in the price of cereals.

In light of the current food crisis and knowing that in the near future we will have to feed an extra 2 to 3 billion people, we must question the world’s food organisation and our consumption patterns.

Feeding the planet is the first Millennium Development Goal (MDG). It is a significant challenge, especially as in the near future, while also properly feeding the 1.5 billion people who are currently starving or malnourished, we must also feed the extra 2 to 3 billion people, with fewer resources available (less water, less oil, less chemical input, less arable land, etc.).

The right to food is a basic human right. However, this public common good is facing massive commercial and financial challenges. The most financially vulnerable countries are the ones paying the heavy price of hunger: domestic subsidies for uneven agricultural production among countries, financial speculation on food, volatile raw material prices, farmland grabbing, etc.

Today, global finance regulates the hunger market, causing riots, trafficking, insecurity and even wars. A world food regulatory body is required, which could steer countries to look beyond their specific short-term interests and lobby private economic players.

It is very unlikely that food can be produced near to mines, including those which are no longer operational. The pollution generated in the air, soil and groundwater makes the surrounding land unusable.

One example can be seen in the Chinese village of Xinguang Sancun, where the fields of watermelons, aubergines and tomatoes have gradually given way to radioactive sludge, driving the local population away because they could no longer feed themselves. The blame lies with the Baotou treatment plants, the “world capital of rare earths”. Hydrometallurgical processes and acid baths are required to process these famous strategic materials used in the manufacture of high-tech products, thereby releasing toxic chemicals and radioactive elements into the atmosphere and the surrounding waters.

Metals have played a key role in what we now call “development”. But are the metals themselves sustainable? Our mining capacities are limited and the reserves of these metals are running out. Certain metals we use, in particular, in the renewable energy sector (antimony, lead and indium) will disappear in 15 to 20 years. The same applies to industrial metals such as zinc, gold or silver. We could go even further and say that the relationship between metals and energy is not sustainable; we talk about a peak all or peak everything: the concentrations of minerals in metals are ever dwindling and an increasing amount of energy is required to extract them. We will soon not know where we can extract our main source of energy.

On the other hand, the environmental impact of metal mining is no longer acceptable and is threatening to cause irreversible damage to whole ecosystems. There are solutions that would improve the sustainability of the metal industry: eco-design, a circular economy and “low-tech” innovations geared towards the simplicity and use of more common resources. The issue we now face is the transition and adaptation of different sectors.

Just like the management of water in certain cities around the world, should metals be managed democratically?

This question is being asked in certain situations, where metal mining by foreign multinationals in a region produces little economic or social benefits for the local population. Bolivia is an example of a country working from the principle that certain natural resources found in the country are considered as common goods. In the eyes of some observers, this approach was the reason behind Evo Morales’ re-election as the President of Bolivia. Will metals one day be managed as a common good?

The pollution caused by metals has serious repercussions on public health. Many scientific studies have shown that the permanent exposure of human beings to small doses of heavy metals, such as cadmium, mercury or lead, is increasingly recognised as one of the co-factors of certain neurological, cardiovascular and autoimmune diseases.

Given the right of each individual to a healthy environment, preventive healthcare strategies to reduce human exposure to heavy metals should be among the priority policies of all countries.

A few years ago, China decided to reduce the quantity of metals that it was willing to export. In fact, the demand among Chinese citizens for rare earths is rising very sharply: smartphones, screens, etc.

How do you tackle such an explosion in demand, doubled by an explosion in the population, with only limited metal resources? This is another pressing problem that is encouraging us to reflect seriously on the circular economy, on eco-design and on our production and consumption of durable goods that require few rare resources. Do we have to endure degrowth for our want of a more resource-efficient path?

While the price of certain metals is generally falling, will rare earths be the new oil of the 21st century?

These rare earths can be found in mobile phones, computer drives, navigation systems and in certain “green technologies” (electric engines, wind turbines, etc.). Consequently, they are highly “strategic” metals. Financial companies are increasingly offering private individuals the option of investing in “rare earths”. Is investing in rare earths like betting on the stocks? It is easy to see the financial sector’s interest in rare earths when we look at the case of the price of dysprosium, which exploded by 2,694% from 2004 to 2013. There has therefore been a rise in the number of speculative investments and financial investors on the metals market.

Modern mining technologies use vast quantities of water. Unfortunately, however, the main link between metals and water is undoubtedly pollution. Metal mining requires a large number of potentially toxic chemicals. The pollution of the oceans by heavy metals (lead, mercury, arsenic, copper, zinc and cadmium) essentially comes from foundries, waste incinerators and abandoned mines.

Despite all that, it makes you think of the godsend of resources in the oceans, which could solve the increasing shortage of metals. Perhaps in the future we could extract the lithium needed for our modern batteries from seawater? In certain countries, the mining industry is also compromising the local population’s water access. This is the case in Mali, where certain gold mines are monopolising a quantity of water that would meet millions of its inhabitants’ needs.

Metals and rare earths are essential for our modern lifestyles and can be found everywhere: in our smartphones, tablets, computer screens, means of transport, energy and communication infrastructures, and even in solar panels.

With 97% of the world’s production, China heavily dominates the global rare earths market, even though it only holds 23% of the world’s reserves. How is this possible? The increasing shortage of resources is generally going to become a more prevalent issue within the institutions in charge of global governance. The decision by countries like China to lower the quantity of metals and rare earths available for exportation, in order to meet its domestic demand, is having an impact on many countries, all of whom depend on these resources. This decision has already led to the first dispute, which required the arbitration of the WTO (World Trade Organisation).

The technological future of our societies and their interdependence will strengthen the need for global governance to address these challenges. All the more so since, in the future, the conquest of resources on other horizons – Mars, the Moon or other planets – could open up new questions: who owns these resources? For whom? Where do we draw the line between public and private goods? Is there a balanced and socially fair economic model?
